title: Labour MP Dawn Butler makes history as she uses sign language in House of Commons
text:
Labour MP Dawn Butler makes history as she uses sign language in House of Commons Watch | MP Dawn Butler asks question in House of Commons using sign language 00:40 Laura Hughes , Political Correspondent 16 March 2017 • 12:21pm 
A Labour MP has made history after using sign language to ask a question in the House of Commons. 
Dawn Butler, the MP for Brent Central , called on the Government to give British Sign Language legal status. 
A Commons spokesman confirmed this was the first time that sign language has been used in the Chamber. Dawn Butler MP 
S peaking as she made the signs, Ms Butler said: “Mr Speaker, I would like to sign my question. 
“Will the Minister agree the 18 of March marks the 14th anniversary since the UK Government recognised British Sign Language. 
“Will the Minister agree (it is) time to bring and get British Sign Language legal status like other recognised languages.” Thankyou to the wonderful Brent & Harrow United #Deaf Club I hope that we can continue to make progress on this issue #BSL #BSLawarenesswk pic.twitter.com/MIolKwN4nV — (((Dawn Butler MP))) (@DawnButlerBrent) March 16, 2017 
B ritish Sign Language recognised by the UK government as an official minority language in 2003. 
However, the British Deaf Association is calling for it to receive the same legal status as Welsh and Scot Gaelic. 
David Lidington, the Leader of the House, said the Department for Education plans to “accept British Sign Language as an alternative qualification to functional skills in England within apprenticeships”. Superb question - brilliantly and thoughtfully delivered - by @DawnButlerBrent https://t.co/KLQNzmz2U7 — Wes Streeting MP (@wesstreeting) March 16, 2017 
H e told MPs: “The honorable lady has very eloquently reminded is of the importance of British Sign Language to a number of our fellow citizens who who live with deafness or sever hearing impairment. 
“The Department for Work and Pensions has underway a review of the provision of signing services in this country. 
“They have had several hundred submissions during the course of that review and the Secretary of State will be bringing forward conclusions in due course.” Follow Telegraph News
